titleStmt.title: Similar functional networks predict performance in both perceptual and value-based decision tasks

affiliation.orgName: Center of AI and Data Science

analytic.title: Similar functional networks predict performance in both perceptual and value-based decision tasks

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: There are numerous commonalities between perceptual and preferential processes. For instance, both perceptual and value-based choices are highly influenced by context which leads to visual illusions and choice biases, respectively. We have previously shown that there is a withinparticipant behavioral relation between a perceptual phenomenon and a value-based bias. However, the neural processes and functional connections that underlie these similarities between perceptual and value-based decisions are still unclear. Hence, in the current study, we examine whether perceptual and preferential processes can be explained by similar functional networks using data from the Human Connectome Project. We used resting-state fMRI data to predict performance of two different decision-making tasks: a value-related task (the delay discounting task) and a perceptual task (the flanker task). We then compared between the functional networks that best predicted each of the tasks. Interestingly, we found a significant positive correlation between the functional networks which predicted the value-based and perceptual tasks. Additionally, a larger functional connectivity between visual and frontal decision brain areas was a critical feature in the prediction of both tasks. These results demonstrate that functional connections between perceptual and value-related areas in the brain are inherently related to decision making processes across domains.

div.p: A major goal across several disciplines such as psychology, neuroscience, and economics is to understand the mechanisms underlying decision-making, both perceptually and value-based.
Perceptual decisions are judgements about sensory input which describe objective states of the world (Gold and Heekeren, 2013). For instance, judging whether a traffic light is green or red.

Whereas, value-based decisions are determined by subjective beliefs and preferences (Rangel et al., 2008), such as whether to invest in a particular stock or not. Although this considerable difference, over the past 20 years, there has been a growing body of literature concerning the similarities and analogies between sensory and value processing. As such, in both sensory perception and value processes there is a transformation of information from objective magnitudes to a subjective scale. In perception, this is known as the Weber-Fechner function (Fechner, 1860), which states that the increase in the perceived magnitude of a certain stimulus declines as the stimulus intensity increases, and in value-based choice it is known as the Bernoulli function, or the utility function (Bernoulli, 1738), which describes the notion that the marginal utility of a certain object declines as the total amount of this object increases. Moreover, several studies demonstrated that value is influenced by context in a similar way as perception (Kahneman, 2002;Louie, Khaw & Glimcher, 2013;Woodford, 2012;Khaw, Li & Woodford, 2017b). For example, Louie and colleagues (2013) have shown that the probability to choose the highest-value product is lower in the presence of a higher-value distractor compared to a lower-value distractor, demonstrating a contrast effect of the context analogous to the Ebbinghaus illusion (Ebbinghaus, 1902) or a contrast effect of color in perception (Song et al., 2019). By the same token, a recent study by Khaw and colleagues (2017) showed that subjects' valuations were lower after continuous exposure to subjectively high-value products (high-value adaptation) and higher after continuous exposure to subjectively low-value products (low-value adaptation), demonstrating an adaptation effect of recent values, similar to the results of perceptual adaptation (Anstis et al., 1998). Additionally, in a previous study, we showed a within-subject relation between a perceptual phenomenon (Gestalt law of proximity) and a value-based bias (attraction effect) (Izakson et al., 2020), which strengthens the notion that there are shared mechanisms between perceptual and preferential processes. Relatedly, context effects of both perceptual and value-based processes can be explained by a single unified theoretical framework, such as divisive normalization (Louie et al., 2013;Khaw et al., 2017;Webb et al., 2021), adaptive gain control (V. Li et al., 2018), or drift-diffusion models (Polanía et al., 2014;Dutilh & Rieskamp, 2016). Interestingly, value modulation was observed in both the visual cortex (Serences, 2008) and the auditory cortex (Brosch et al., 2011) in a modality-specific way (Shuster & Levy, 2018).

Moreover, it was shown that value modulation of visual areas account for the attentional bias towards the more valued option (Jahfari et al., 2020). Additionally, enhancement in the activity of frontal areas, which are associated with value-related processes, such as the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC), and anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) (Purves et al., 2008), account for perceptual learning that occur in tasks such as the dynamic random dot task (Jia et al., 2018), or a navigation task (Patai & Spiers, 2021).

This evidence strengthens the notion that perceptual and value-based decisions are not distinct processes with their own set of specific relevant brain areas, but rather they share a similar functional organization. Relatedly, in a thorough review, Yoo and Hayden (2018) proposed that visual and value-based processes may be two parts of a larger process that yields actions based on sensory input, and thus, understanding the connectivity between specific brain areas, which underlie them rather than the activity within each region seperately, is important for understanding decision-making processes across domains.

Additionally, the neural processes and functional connections that underlie the similarities between perceptual and value-based decisions are still unclear. Therefore, in this study, we first examine the functional connections, which underlie perceptual and value-based processes, and then examine whether both of these decision processes can be explained by similar functional networks. Following previous evidence from task-related studies (Serences, 2008;Jahfari et al., 2020;Jia et al., 2018;Patai & Spiers, 2021), we hypothesized that a stronger functional connectivity between brain areas that are related to perceptual and value-based processes would better predict behavioral performance in both perceptual and value-based decision-making tasks.

To examine this, we used resting-state (rs) fMRI data from the Human Connectome Project (HCP). This dataset is comprised from over 1,000 well-assessed healthy adults, which allows us to apply a predictive framework on a large homogeneous resting-state fMRI dataset. In a standard resting-state experiment, subjects are instructed to lay awake in the scanner while no explicit task is introduced (Biswal et al., 1995). The rs-fMRI signal is analyzed to extract patterns of functional connectivity, reflecting time-synchronous activity of spatially distinct brain areas commonly represented as the rs-connectome (Sporns, 2011). This is termed functional connectivity since brain areas that are highly correlated in time are considered to be engaged in common or related processing (Rosenberg et al., 2015). Additionally, rs-connectomes are thought to describe stable aspects of brain organization (Shen et al., 2017) as well as inherent features of brain activity, which are also associated with task-dependent activity (Tavor et al., 2016). In recent years, it has been shown that functional connectivity during rest could be used to predict various behavioral measurements (N. Li et al., 2013;Poole et al., 2016;Cai et al., 2020;Gal et al., 2022) and personality traits (Dubois et al., 2018). Thus, using resting-state functional connectivity would allow us to examine the inherent functional connections that are evident without any specific behavioral task, which underlie each decision type, and not only focus on the neural activity of distinct brain areas during the decision itself as previous studies have done (Kable & Glimcher, 2007;Chau et al., 2014;Rigoli et al., 2016;Jia et al., 2018;Patai & Spiers, 2021).

Here, we use the rs-connectome to predict performance in two different tasks: a value-based decision-making task (the delay discounting task) and a perceptual decision-making task (the flanker task). Then, we examine the similarity between the functional networks that best predicted the behavior in each of these tasks.

Delay discounting describes the extent that people undervalue rewards that are delayed in time (Frederick et al., 2003;Kable & Glimcher, 2007). This decline in the perceived value of a delayed reward differs across individuals (Kable & Glimcher, 2007). In a standard delay discounting task, in each trial, participants choose between two options: a smaller amount "today" or a larger amount at a later point in time. The extent in which the delayed amount has to be larger than the immediate amount for the participant to choose it indicates the participant's delay discounting tendencies. The flanker task measures information processing and selective attention (Eriksen & Eriksen, 1974). Participants need to focus on a given stimulus and respond to its perceptual properties (i.e., decide which direction the arrow is pointing) while inhibiting attention to other stimuli that are pointing to the other direction (flanked). Interestingly, both the flanker task (Takezawa & Miyatani, 2005) and the delay discounting task (Basile & Toplak, 2015) require executive functions such as conflict monitoring and response inhibition, which strengthen our hypothesis that similar functional networks would predict both tasks.

Previous studies have shown that the discount rate across participants can be predicted using functional networks. For instance, Cai and colleagues (2020) showed that multiple brain systems are involved in the prediction of the discount rates including the default mode-(DMN), subcortical-, somatomotor-, dorsal attention-, and visual-networks. Additionally, (N. Li et al., 2013) showed that higher functional connectivity between value-related brain areas (e.g., ventro medial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC), posterior cingulate cortex (PCC), and striatum) predicts higher discounting rates in the delay discounting task across participants. Regarding the flanker task, as far as we know, there are no studies that attempted to predict individual variation in performance using functional connectivity. However, studies that attempted to predict selective attention using functional connectivity in other tasks (e.g., singleton paradigm), showed that greater within-DMN connectivity better predicted was predictive of better distractor suppression, while greater connectivity between the DMN and attention networks better predicted was predictive of poorer distractor suppression (Poole et al., 2016). Moreover, frontal decision areas such as the ACC and dlPFC have been associated with success in the flanker task (Blasi et al., 2006;Geissler et al., 2020). These studies strengthen the notion that performance in value-based tasks is associated with processes within perceptual visual areas in addition to the "classic" decision areas, and that behavior in perceptual tasks is associated with activity in frontal decision areas in addition to "classic" perceptual areas.

In this study, we aimed to demonstrate that similar functional networks can be used to predict behavioral performance in both the delay discounting and the flanker tasks. The use of functional connectivity measures allowed us to understand the task-independent neural connections which underlie the behavioral similarities between perceptual and value-based processes. Specifically, we hypothesized that functional connectivity between visual and frontal decision brain areas would be associated with the performance in both tasks.

div.head: Data set
div.p: We used data from the 1,200 participant-release of the HCP data set (http://www.humanconnectome.org). The HCP provides MRI data and extensive behavioral assessment from almost 1,200 participants. These subjects are healthy young adults within an age range of 22-37 years. Acquisition parameters and preprocessing steps of the resting-state fMRI data are described in depth in the original publication (Glasser et al., 2013). Briefly, each participant underwent two sessions of rs-fMRI on separate days. Each session had two separate acquisition scans lasting 14:34 min each, resulting in a total of four resting-state fMRI scans. The scans were conducted in a customized Siemens Skyra (Siemens Medical Solutions, NJ, USA) 3

Tesla MRI scanner, repetition time (TR) =720 ms, echo time (TE)=33 ms, flip angle=52°, voxel size=2mm isotropic, 72 slices, matrix=104 × 90, field of view (FOV)=208 × 180 mm, multiband acceleration factor=8). The two scans acquired on the same day differed in the phase encoding direction, left-right and right-left (which leads to differential signal intensity especially in ventral temporal and frontal structures). The HCP data were downloaded in its de-noised preprocessed form, that is, after distortion correction, motion correction, field bias correction, spatial transformation, normalization into a common Montreal Neurological Institute space (Glasser et al., 2013), and artifact removal using independent component analysis (ICA) and FMRIB's ICAbased Xnoiseifier (FIX) (Salimi-Khorshidi et al., 2014;Griffanti et al., 2014). Specifically, we used the MSM-All data (Robinson et al., 2018), in which inter-subject registration utilizes metrics such as individual cortical folding, myelin maps, and rs-fMRI correlation data.

div.head: Behavioral assessment
div.p: The HCP dataset provides an extensive behavioral assessment from 1206 participants.
Specifically, for the purpose of this study, we used two behavioral assessments: delay discounting and flanker task scores.

div.head: Delay discounting task
div.p: Delay discounting describes the undervaluing of rewards that are delayed in time (Frederick et al., 2003;Kable & Glimcher, 2007). A detailed description of the delay discounting measure can be found in the HCP_S1200_Release_Reference_Manual.pdf on the HCP website. In brief, on each trial, participants had to choose between two options: a smaller amount "today" or a larger amount at a later point in time. Participants made choices involving 6 "later" time periods (1 month, 6 months, 1 year, 3 years, 5 years, and 10 years) and two delayed amounts ($200 and $40,000).

Each "larger later" combination of time period and delayed amount (e.g., $200 in 1 month or $40,000 in 6 months), was repeated 5 times. The participants made all five choices for a particular combination of time period and delayed amount before moving on to the next combination of time period and delayed amount. The first trial of every block was between the fixed delayed amount (either $200 or $40,000) and an immediate amount equal to one half of the delayed amount (e.g., $100 today or $200 in 1 month, or $20,000 today or $40,000 in one month). The immediate amount on the next trial was adjusted according to the participant's previous response. That is, a smaller amount if the participant chose the immediate amount on the previous trial or larger if she chose the delayed amount. Based on participant's choices, a discount function for each delayed amount ($200 and $40,000) was calculated for each participant. Finally, the area under each of the discount functions (area-under-the-curve; AUC) for each participant in each delayed amount (DDisc_AUC_200 and DDisc_AUC_40k) was computed to provide a valid and reliable estimate of the degree in which a participant discounts delayed rewards (Myerson et al., 2001). This variable was selected due to its good psychometric properties; a smaller AUC reflects greater delay discounting, i.e., a greater decision impulsivity.

div.head: Flanker task
div.p: The Eriksen flanker task is a perceptual decision-making task, which measures information processing and selective attention (Eriksen & Eriksen, 1974). A detailed description of the flanker task can be found in the HCP_S1200_Release_Reference_Manual.pdf on the HCP website and the NIH toolbox cognition battery web page (https://www.healthmeasures.net/exploremeasurement-systems/nih-toolbox/intro-to-nih-toolbox/cognition). In brief, participants were presented with a row of 5 arrows and had to choose whether the central arrow pointed to the left or to the right. The flanking arrows were either pointing to the same direction (congruent condition) as the central arrow or pointing to the opposite direction (incongruent condition). The flanker scores were a normed combination of accuracy and reaction time (RT). That is, the number of correct trials based on both congruent and incongruent trials was calculated and for subjects whose accuracy was above 80%, a rescaled log RT values were added to the score (rescaled scores were reversed such that smaller RT log values were at the upper end of the 0-5 range whereas larger RT log values were at the lower end). Thus, higher flanker scores represent a better performance in the task. We used the Flanker_AgeAdj scores ( Fig. 2A), which adjusted the final score according to participant's age for the subsequent prediction analyses.

div.head: Participants
div.p: The total number of participants in the 1,200-participant release of the HCP data set is N=1206. We applied the following criteria to include/exclude participants from our analyses: 1) participants must have completed all resting-state fMRI scans, which resulted in 1003 participants. 2) Participants must have completed both flanker and delay discounting tasks, which resulted in 992 participants. We further excluded participants that were 3 standard deviations away from the mean of the distribution either in the delay discounting score or the flanker score.
As such, the final sample we used consisted of 990 participants.

div.head: Construction of functional connectomes
div.p: For each participant, we first demeaned and normalized each of the four rs-fMRI scans and then concatenated them into a continuous time series consisting of 4800 time points. We then used a local-global parcellation, which divides the brain into 100 nodes based on 7 "canonical" resting-state networks described by (Yeo et al., 2011), developed for functional network connectivity analysis (Schaefer et al., 2018). We then extracted the time series by averaging data from all grayordinates (i.e., the surface representation of gray matter voxels) within each node, and generated the functional connectivity matrix for each subject by pairwise correlating between node time series, which resulted in a Pearson correlation coefficient between each two nodes.

Thereafter, we normalized the correlation coefficients using Fisher's z-transformation. These steps resulted in a 100X100 functional connectivity matrix (or connectome) representing the connectivity between all node pairs for each participant. Since the resulting functional connectivity matrices are symmetric around the diagonal, we used only the bottom half of the matrices, which resulted in 4950 edges (or features), to predict the delay discounting and the flanker tasks.

div.head: Feature selection
div.p: To avoid overfitting due to the high number of predictors (4950) relative to the number of observations (N=990), we first used a feature selection method to reduce the number of predictors. We filtered the features according to their simple correlation with the behavioral scores in the training set. We kept the top 5% of the features in terms of the size of their Pearson correlation coefficient in absolute value with the behavioral variable (Shen et al., 2017). After this procedure, we were left with 247 features that entered the training stage.

div.head: Prediction models
div.p: We used an elastic-net connectome-based predictive modelling (CPM), which is a regularized linear regression based on elastic-net penalization (Zou & Hastie, 2005;Dubois et al., 2018) to predict the flanker and delay discounting scores. Specifically, we used a fixed L1 ratio (the weight between L1 (Lasso) and L2 (Ridge) regularizations) of 0.01, which amounts to an almost pure ridge regression. Additionally, we used a nested 10-fold cross validation routine to choose the penalty factor (among 7 possible values ranging from 0.0001 to 10), considering the family structure in the HCP data. In each iteration, a model was trained on 9/10 of the data, and predictions were yielded for 1/10 of the data. Note, that we separated genetically related participants to either the training or the test datasets. The significance levels of the models were determined using a permutation test in which the real correlation between the observed and predicted behavioral measurement was compared to a random permutation (N=10,000). Notably, we conducted the same feature selection method and prediction model to predict both the delay discounting and the flanker scores.

div.head: Comparison between the functional networks which best predicted each task
div.p: After predicting the performance of each task separately, we compared the functional networks that best predicted each of the tasks. Specifically, we wanted to compare the standardized coefficients of the 247 selected features of each model. However, since not necessarily the same 247 features were selected for each model, we opted to reduce the spatial resolution of our features (Fig. 1). As such, we used all the 4950 possible features and assigned a "coefficient" of zero for the unselected features (i.e., not part of the 247 features that were selected in the feature selection method) [ Fig. 1B]. Then, we grouped the features according to the seven networks that were described by (Yeo et al., 2011), while retaining the hemispheric division (so we can have a differentiation between inter-and intra-hemispheric connections) [ Fig. 1B]. For instance, the features RH_vis1 -LH_cont_PFCl1 and RH_vis1 -LH_cont_Cing1 were grouped under the aggregated feature RH_vis -LH_cont. Then, for each group of features, we calculated the average coefficient across the coefficients of the aggregated features in absolute value (Fig. 1C), resulting in a total of 14 nodes (7 nodes per hemisphere) and 105 aggregated features. Beforehand, we validated that there is a coherence in the direction of the coefficients for the aggregated features so it would make sense to average across them and use absolute value (a detailed description is available in the Supplementary Information). Otherwise, if the coefficients of a certain pair of networks would be in different directions, they would cancel each other when we average across them. We then performed a spearman correlation analysis to compare between the coefficients of the 105 aggregated features of each model and validated the significance using a permutation test (N=10,000).

div.head: Seed-to-vertex analysis and connectivity-behavior analysis
div.p: As a complementary analysis, we used seed-to-vertex analysis (Biswal et al., 1995;Fox et al., 2005;Shou et al., 2014). Following our hypothesis that stronger functional connectivity between visual and frontal areas is associated with both value-based and perceptual tasks, we selected a primary visual cortex (V1) seed area (using a mask of Brodmann area 17 (Fig. 5C)) and calculated the correlation coefficient (r) between the time series of the visual seed and the time series of all other vertices in the brain (91,281 vertices). This way we obtained a seed-tovertex connectivity map for each participant showing the functional connectivity between the visual seed area and all other vertices in the brain. We Fisher Z transformed the correlation coefficients (r) to generate a z-functional connectivity (FC) map for each participant. Then, we generated seed-to-vertex-to-behavior maps by correlating the Fisher z scores of each vertex with the behavioral scores across participants separately for each behavioral task (DDisc_AUC_40k and flanker task scores). To determine the significance level of each vertex's correlation coefficient value, we reconstructed a null distribution by performing a permutation test with 5000 iterations, where in each iteration we scrambled the behavioral scores and repeated the abovementioned analysis. The p-value of each vertex is then defined by the following equation:

Where describes the number of permutations, Next, we transformed the p-values to z-values and clustered them with a minimal value of z=1.96 and a minimal cluster size of 20 * . This analysis allowed us to detect brain areas that the connectivity between them and the visual seed was most associated with the behavioral scores.

To further compare between the clusters that were found for each of the main tasks, we calculated a Dice index (DI) (Dice, 1945), which takes into account the intersection between the clusters that were associated with the V1 seed and each of the main tasks as well as the overall area of each task's clusters. It is defined by the following equation:

Where " represents the number of vertices whose connectivity with the V1 seed was associated with behavioral scores of a specific task (e.g., the flanker task) and + represents the number of vertices whose connectivity with the V1 seed was associated with behavioral scores of the other task (e.g., the delay discounting task).

div.head: Characterization of behavioral measures
div.p: In order to compare between the functional connections, which are associated with perceptual and preferential processes, we used two decision tasks from the HCP data: a perceptual task (the flanker task) and a value-based task (the delay discounting task). In our final participant sample (N=990), the average flanker task's score across participants was 102.12 (SD=9.97, ranging from 71.24 to 123.56; Fig. 2A). As for the delay discounting task, the average AUC score of the $40K amount (DDisc_AUC_40K) was 0.51 (SD=0.28, ranging from 0.02 to 0.98; Fig. 2B), and the average AUC score of the $200 amount (DDisc_AUC_200) was 0.26 (SD=0.2.

ranging from 0.02 to 0.98; Supplementary Figure 1B). Unsurprisingly, there is a high correlation between these two measurements (R=.66, p<.0001; Supplementary Figure 1C). We chose to use the scores of the $40K amount (DDisc_AUC_40K scores) as the value-based behavioral measurement we aim to predict, since it is uniformly distributed as opposed to the skewed distribution of the $200 amount (DDisc_AUC_200 scores). A more uniform distribution provides superior predictability since there is an equal representation of the whole score range, which makes it easier for the model to learn the whole range and reduces biases in prediction. This was also demonstrated by (Cai et al., 2020). Nevertheless, our analysis using the $200 amount (DDisc_AUC_200 scores) yielded similar results as our main results (Supplementary information).

div.head: Prediction performance
div.p: We used the rs-connectomes to predict each of the decision tasks using an elastic-net regression. Regarding the delay discounting task, we were able to significantly predict both the AUC scores of the $40K amount (DDisc_AUC_40K) [r=0.28, p<0.0001; Fig. 3A] and of the $200 amount (DDisc_AUC_200) [r = 0.25, p<0.0001; Supplementary Figure 2A] which replicates findings from a previous study (Cai et al., 2020).

As for the flanker task, the elastic-net regression significantly predicted the flanker scores (Flanker_AgeAdj) as well (r=0.12, p<0.05; Fig. 3B). This demonstrates for the first time, as far as we know, that performance in the flanker task could be predicted using rs-connectomes.

Additionally, in line with our hypothesis, functional connections between visual and frontal areas were among the features that contributed the most to the prediction of performance in both value and perceptual tasks ( Fig. 3C-F). Specifically, as can be seen in figures 3E and 3F, both intra-and inter-hemisphere functional connections between visual and frontal areas were among the 5% most important features in the prediction of performance in both decision tasks.

div.head: Common functional networks predict both value and perceptual tasks' performance
div.p: To compare between the functional networks, which predicted the performance in each decision task, we quantitatively examine the extent of the overlap between the standardized coefficients of the features of each model. Specifically, we grouped the features (which describe edges -functional connections between nodes) of each of the two models into the seven networks that were described by Yeo et al., (2011) by calculating the average coefficient in absolute value across all the features that are related to one of the seven large networks (see a detailed description in the Methods). We retained the hemispheric division to have a differentiation between inter-and intra-hemispheric connections.

Consistent with our hypothesis, we observed a significant positive correlation between the coefficients of the aggregated features, which predicted the delay discounting and flanker tasks (Spearman R=0.6, p<0.0001; Fig. 4A). This suggests that the functional connections that predicted each of the decision tasks are similar. Additionally, we found that the largest coefficients in both models are mainly functional connections between visual and frontal areas, and between visual and ventral attention areas (see the circled points in Fig. 4A).

Moreover, we found a significant positive correlation between the aggregated features of related behavioral measures, such as the DDisc_AUC_40k scores (AUC scores of the $40K amount) and of the DDisc_AUC_200 scores (AUC scores of the $200 amount) [Supplementary Figure 3A], as well as the DDisc_AUC_200 scores and the flanker scores (Supplementary Figure 3B), which further suggests that tasks with shared mechanisms would have similar resting-state functional networks which predict them.

To examine whether the significant positive correlation we found between the features is specific to these two tasks and is not evident for every two tasks, we performed the same analysis with seven other tasks taken from the HCP. That is, we correlated the coefficients of the aggregated features, which predicted a control task, with the coefficients of the aggregated features, which predicted either the delay discounting task or the flanker task. We chose these additional tasks as they are conceptually not directly related to neither perceptual nor value-based decision-making processes. For instance, one such control measurement was the psychological trait, "openness to experience" (termed "NEOFAC_O" in the HCP dataset), which was measured using the 60-item version of the (Fig. 4C), nor the coefficients of the flanker model (Fig. 4D) were significantly correlated with the coefficients of the openness model. Similarly, none of the aggregated features of the other six control models showed a significant positive correlation with the aggregated features of the models of the decision tasks ( Fig. 4B; Supplementary Figure 4).

Note, however, that there were two control tasks whose aggregated features showed a significant negative correlation with the aggregated features of one of the decision tasks (Fig. 4B). That is, the aggregated features of the reading model were negatively correlated with the aggregated features of the delay discounting model (Supplementary Figure 4A), and the aggregated features of the endurance model was negatively correlated with the aggregated features of the flanker model ( Supplementary Figure 4J). In the context of our study, since we were interested in the similarity between the features of the aggregated features of different models, negative correlation means that when the coefficient of a certain aggregated feature was large in one model, it was low in the other model, which suggests that there is low similarity between the models since the important features used for prediction in each model are different.

These results indicate that the significant positive correlation, which we found between the coefficients of the delay discounting model and the flanker model is unique and is not evident for any two tasks. This strengthens the notion that the delay discounting task and the flanker task have common neural mechanisms.

div.head: Further investigation of the common functional connections using seed-to-vertex analysis
div.p: To examine which specific brain areas are associated with the visual area and each of the behavioral measurements (delay discounting and flanker scores), we conducted an additional seed-to-vertex analysis followed by a connectivity-behavior analysis. Specifically, we examined the correlations between the functional connections of the primary visual cortex (V1) and all other vertices in the brain and the behavioral scores (delay discounting and flanker task scores, separately).

Consistent with our previous results, we found that functional connections between the V1 seed area and frontal decision areas (PCC, dlPFC, inferior frontal gyrus [IFG]) as well as with parietal areas, which are part of the ventral attention network (the right tempo-parietal junction, rTPJ) were associated with both the delay discounting (turquoise areas in Fig. 5) and flanker scores (orange areas in Fig. 5). The intersection of both tasks is presented in the yellow areas in Fig. 5 (DI = 0.57).

As a control analysis, we performed the same procedure on all the control tasks that were used in the previous section to examine whether these brain areas (PCC, dlPFC, IFG, and rTPJ) are associated with the V1 seed area for any task or is it specific to perceptual and value-based decision tasks. For instance, in figure 5, we can see in black, the brain areas that are associated with the V1 seed area and one of the control tasks -list sorting (this task assess working memory, see https://wiki.humanconnectome.org/display/PublicData/HCP-YA+Data+Dictionary-+Updated+for+the+1200+Subject+Release for further details). These areas include parts of the dorsal and ventral visual streams, ACC, and the lateral frontopolar cortex. Importantly, these are different brain areas compared to the areas that we found to be associated with the V1 seed area in both the delay discounting and flanker tasks (the value of the DI when compared to either of the main tasks equals 0; Supplementary Figure 6H). In fact, for all of the control tasks, the clusters that were associated with the V1 seed area were different than the clusters that were found to be associated with the V1 seed area in the flanker and delay discounting tasks (detailed results for each of the control tasks are presented in Supplementary Figure 6). These findings further demonstrate that functional connections between visual and frontal areas as well as visual and ventral attention areas are associated with both the delay discounting and flanker tasks. Clusters for which functional connectivity strength (Fisher z) with the V1 seed (red color on the right) was significantly positively associated with the delay discounting (DD) scores (turquoise color) and flanker (F) scores (orange color). The common areas (intersection) between these two tasks are represented in yellow (DI = 0.57). The areas that were associated with the V1 seed and an exemplary control task (List sorting) are presented in black.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In the current study, we examined the neural commonalities between perceptual and valuebased decision-making tasks using resting-state fMRI data from the HCP. First, we were able to successfully predict the behavioral performance in both a perceptual and a value-based decisionmaking tasks. Our results replicate previous research on the predictability of delay discounting scores using rs-fMRI data (Cai et al., 2020), and, as far as we know, show for the first time that performance in the flanker task could be predicted in a similar way. Importantly, consistent with our hypothesis, functional connectivity between visual and frontal decision brain areas, as well as between visual and ventral attention areas were among the most important features in the prediction of the performance in both tasks. Our finding that both attention and decision brain areas are associated with decision-making is in line with many previous studies that demonstrated a behavioral connection between attention and value-based decision making (Anderson et al., 2011;Anderson, 2013;Bourgeois, Chelazzi, & Vuilleumier, 2016;Gluth et al., 2018). For instance,
Anderson and colleagues (2011) showed that participants tend to direct their attention to stimuli previously associated with reward.

Moreover, we demonstrated that the significant positive correlation between the functional connections that predicted the delay discounting and flanker scores is specific, as we did not observe such a significant positive correlation when using other tasks, which are not directly related to neither perceptual nor decision-making processes. This suggests that the significant positive correlation we found between the coefficients of the delay discounting and flanker models only occur when the two tasks share underlying mechanisms. This strengthens previous studies which showed that similar tasks share similar brain areas (Brown et al., 2006;Fehr et al., 2007), but in addition it provides evidence that related tasks share similar functional networks during rest.

Furthermore, the additional seed-to-vertex analysis allowed us to examine what are the specific frontal and attention areas that are associated with the primary visual area and each of the decision tasks (delay discounting and flanker scores). The frontal decision areas that we found to be associated with the V1 seed and the behavioral scores were the PCC, dlPFC, and IFG, and the parietal (ventral attention) area was the rTPJ.

Each of the specific frontal decision areas that we identified in this analysis is associated with a different aspect of decision-making. The PCC has been associated with positive subjective value (Bartra et al., 2013), and the dlPFC has been associated with executive functions (Dubreuil-Vall et al., 2019), specifically with conflict monitoring, choice (Rangel & Hare, 2010), and response inhibition (Fan et al., 2003), which are common necessities of both tasks (Takezawa & Miyatani, 2005;Basile & Toplak, 2015). The dlPFC was also associated with cost-benefit calculation between alternatives (Duncan & Owen, 2000). As for the IFG, recent studies highlighted its importance in working memory and cognitive flexibility in decision-making (Reckless et al., 2014) as well as risk preferences (Christopoulos et al., 2009), and the right IFG has been also connected to executive functions such as inhibition and attention control (Hampshire et al., 2010). Regarding the parietal area, which we identified in this analysis, the rTPJ, it has been shown to be involved in the processing of information in terms of the ability of an individual to orient attention to new stimuli (Corbetta et al., 2000). These results further demonstrate that functional connections between visual and ventral attention areas as well as visual and frontal decision areas during rest are associated with both perceptual and preferential decision-making tasks. This indicates that the brain uses similar neural processes for both types of decisions which strengthens the notion that the brain generalizes across domains.

Moreover, the fact that these functional connections are measured during rest provides evidence that the connections between visual and frontal decision areas as well as visual and ventral attention areas are inherent features of both perceptual and value-based decision-making processes and that they are present even when the participant is not actively engaged in a task.

This demonstrates that the same inherent connectivity patterns underlie both types of decision processes, which may suggest that basic neuronal principles could be at the heart of what seems to be different cognitive processes from different domains, such as perception and decision making.

Notably, albeit the neural commonalities that we have demonstrated here, there are also studies regarding the differences between perceptual and value-based processes (Polanía et al., 2014;Dutilh & Rieskamp, 2016). For instance, Polanía and collegues (2014) demonstrated that for both types of decisions, there was a similar EEG signal originating from parietal areas underlying evidence accumulation, whereas a similar frontal signal for evidence accumulation was unique for value-based decisions. Hence, although we have demonstrated the inherent common neural mechanisms between the two types of decisions during rest, there are also some differences, which may be manifested during the process of the decision itself. Relatedly, in our data we also observed some differences between the functional networks which predicted each of the decision tasks. That is, part of the most important features for the prediction of the delay discounting were connections between parietal selective attention and frontal areas as well as inter-hemisphere frontal connections, which were not part of the important features for the prediction of performance in the flanker task.

Our study has several limiting factors that should be mentioned. First, we demonstrated the functional commonalities between perceptual and value-based tasks using two specific tasks (flanker and delay discounting). Future studies should compare between additional perceptual and value-based tasks to determine the robustness of our findings. Moreover, even though the use of resting-state data enabled an inquiry of trait networks that underlie our processes of interest, it would be beneficial in the future to also use task-related fMRI data to compare between perceptual and value-based processes. Recent studies showed that there is an added value for using task-related functional connectivity in addition to rest data for prediction models (Greene et al., 2018;Sripada et al., 2020). Although, there is a value-based decision task that was conducted inside the MRI scanner in the HCP data (termed Gambling in the HCP dataset), there was not an appropriate perceptual decision-making task, which we could use as a comparison.
In conclusion, we reliably predicted the performance in both delay discounting and flanker tasks using resting-state functional connectivity data from a large-scale data set. Our findings

show that there is a significant positive correlation between the functional connections that predicted both tasks. Specifically, functional connections between visual and frontal decision areas as well as visual and ventral attention areas during rest were among the most predictive features in the prediction of both the delay discounting and flanker tasks. This indicates that these functional connections are inherent features of both perceptual and value-based decision-making processes, which strengthens the notion that these tasks share common neural processes and might be explained using a single general framework.

div.head: Conflict of Interest:
div.p: All authors declare no conflict of interest.

figure.head: Fig 1 .
figure.figDesc: Resolution decrease pipeline. (A) Each model is represented by a column of rectangles and each rectangle is a feature in the model. The selected features are represented by different colors and the unselected ones are gray. Only the K selected features are part of each model. (B) Assignment of zero to all the unselected features in each model (represented by white color), and grouping of the features according to N networks is represented by the colored bounding-boxes that surround each group of features. (C) Averaging the coefficients of the grouped features. Note, the image contains a representative number of features.

"# ) describes the Pearson correlation between the Fisher z scores of each vertex with the real behavioral scores across participants in absolute value, and ( $ ) describes the Pearson correlation between the Fisher z scores of each vertex with the permutated behavioral scores across participants in absolute value.

figure.head: Fig 2 .
figure.figDesc: Behavioral results. Histograms describing participants' results in (A) the flanker task (mean=102.12, SD=9.97), and in (B) the delay discounting task for the $40K amount (mean=0.51, SD=0.28). n=990. The dashed black line represents the mean.

figure.head: Fig 3 .
figure.figDesc: Prediction results of delay discounting and flanker scores. (A) and (B) Scatter plots showing the correlation between actual (x-axis) and predicted (y-axis) task scores based on the functional connectivity features. (A) describes DDisc_AUC_40k scores (i.e., AUC scores of the $40K amount) [R = 0.28, p = 0.0002] and (B) describes flanker task scores (R = 0.12, p = 0.04). (C) and (D) The 50 most important functional connections for prediction (both positive and negative functional connections) of DDisc_AUC_40k and flanker task scores. (E) and (F) The 5% most important functional connections for prediction (both positive and negative functional connections) of DDisc_AUC_40k and flanker task scores superimposed on a brain. The node colors represent one of the 7 known resting-state networks based on(Yeo et al., 2011). The edge colors represent if it was a positive (red) or a negative (blue) functional connection.

figure.head: Fig 4 .
figure.figDesc: Model comparison results. (A)A correlation between the coefficients of the aggregated features, which predicted the delay discounting (DD)-and the flanker (F) -tasks (Spearman R=0.6, p<0.0001). (B) A bar graph displaying the correlation coefficients (spearman R) of the aggregated features, which predicted different pairs of tasks. The p-value is displayed on top of each bar. (C) and (D) A correlation between the coefficients of the aggregated features, which predicted the openness and delay discounting scores (C) (Spearman R=0.04, p=0.88), and the openness and flanker scores (D) (Spearman R=-0.1, p=0.55).

div.head: Acknowledgments:
div.p: The authors thank lab members for constructive comments and fruitful suggestions. Special thank you to Asaf Madar and Niv Tik for their valuable advice throughout the work on the study.
Funding: This work was supported by the Jeremy Coller Foundation. The funding sources had no role in study design, collection, analysis, interpretation, or decision to submit this paper.
